statement:
Let $G$ be a group, then $G$ is isomorphic to a subgroup of the
permutation group $S_{G}$

If $G$ is finite and of order $n$, then $G$ is isomorphic to a subgroup
of the permutation group $S_{n}$

Furthermore, suppose $H$ is a proper subgroup of $G$. Let
$X = \{Hg | g \in G\}$ be the set of right cosets in $G$. The map
$\theta:G \to S_{X}$ given by $\theta(x)(Hg) = Hgx$ is a homomorphism.
The kernel is the largest normal subgroup of $H$. We note that
$|S_X| = [G : H]!$. Consequently if $|G|$ doesn’t divide $[G :  H]!$
then $\theta$ is not an isomorphism so $H$ contains a non-trivial normal
subgroup, namely the kernel of $\theta$.
